DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Demand Faster Liberalization
DOC.TEXT: Parliament deputies on Saturday demanded more democracy and improvements in the economy as they debated whether to give a vote of confidence to the new government of Prime Minister Mudar Badran. Lawmakers predicted that approval of Badran's 25-member Cabinet was likely in the vote Sunday, despite the tough attacks on his government. The debate caps a revival of life in the Parliament. Last month, Jordan held its first general elections in 22 years. King Hussein on Dec. 4 named Badran to form a new government. The Cabinet he formed will have the task of negotiating with Parliament on new legislation, but first it must win a vote of confidence from Parliament. Twenty members of the Moslem Brotherhood, the largest bloc in the 80-man Parliament, said in a joint statement they would abstain unless the government agreed to stricter Islamic laws, quick repeal of martial law, reinstatement of public officials fired for security reasons and a ban on liquor sales in public places, including aboard Royal Jordanian airline flights. The large number of deputies rising to address Parliament forced Speaker Suleiman Arar to postpone a vote on the question until Sunday. Abdullatif Arabiyyat, delivering the Brotherhood's joint statement, said Brotherhood deputies had told Badran earlier that they would cooperate ``with a strong, clean government,'' although efforts to agree on ministerial seats for the Brotherhood collapsed. ``And then we were faced with a surprise ... a government that was much below the level of our aspirations and the aspirations of the people,'' he said. Hundreds of people jammed the public galleries for the debate, sometimes applauding deputies below. About 100 others demonstrated in front of the building to demand immediate freedom for political prisoners. Even some steadfast loyalists of the king said they would vote against the new government, despite a series of measures by Badran to loosen martial law, restrict the security forces and free the press. Former Royal Court Chief Thouqan Hindawi accused Badran of helping create the kingdom's debt crisis during earlier terms as prime minister from 1979 to 1983, and he said it was difficult to determine how the money was spent. ``Where is the rest of the money, Mr. Badran?'' asked Hindawi, who resigned as King Hussein's chief aide to run for Parliament in November during Jordan's first nationwide election since 1967. Economic problems caused by the debt crisis led to four days of rioting in April that toppled the government of then-Prime Minister Zaid Rifai and led Hussein to launch a series of liberalizing measures. Many Jordanians allege that government corruption caused much of the economic problems. Since taking office, Badran's government has eliminated some of the security checks for passports and work permits and has stripped most of the work from martial law courts, as well as liberalizing the press. But many of the deputies speaking Saturday demanded full repeal of martial law, imposed during the 1967 war with Israel, and legalization of political parties banned more than 30 years ago. Some also called for investigations into the country's economic distress and trials of those deemed responsible.
